text: [music playing]

HAIM SABAN: We stuck to the
original concept of having
a very diversified cast.

I don't think a lot of
movies take that kind of risk

of having a maybe gay
character as a superhero and
an autistic kid as a superhero.

So we've always
been very different.

We've always been cutting
edge in terms of diversity,

and we just continued
with that tradition.

BECKY G.: Being a
shero is a big deal.

I remember growing up there
not being a big representation

of females in the
industry, let alone females

that were able to
hang with the boys.

And I think that's what's
so cool about this movie
is it's all about equality.

Those things aren't even
mentioned because it
shouldn't be putting walls.
We shouldn't be put into boxes.
[music playing]

DEAN ISRAELITE: I think,
in that scene, what's

clear is that she has a lot of
questions about her identity,

and she hasn't fully
figured it out yet.

And the movie lets you
know that that's OK.

And I think that that's
what that moment is about.

LUDI LIN: It's all
about diversity,

and I think the more diverse it
is, the more people can relate
to it, especially little kids.

NAOMI SCOTT: Going
into this movie,

I was like, right, Kimberly,
the character of Kimberly.

And that's how I approached
it as an actress.

I was like, right, my
responsibility is to Kimberly
and the character of Kimberly.

And then everything that's
really fun and iconic

about Power Rangers, like
being in the suit, that's
all built into the script.

So honestly, it's
just excitement.

I'm just really
excited to hopefully
do that character justice.
